intro: Corunastylis systena, commonly known as the golden mistflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, branching stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowering period attracts various pollinators, including bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance. The plant is often found in sandy or rocky soils in open habitats such as woodlands and heathlands.
